children.name: treatment for an injury or illness
treatment
children.definition: a medical method of curing someone who is ill or injured, for example by means of drugs or an operation:
examples: phép điều trị
treatment for sth
điều trị cho cái gì đó
▪ Doctors are trying out a new treatment for depression.
treatment of st
điều trị của cái gì đó
▪ Natural poisons such as snake venom are now being used in the treatment of human nervous disorders.
receive treatment
nhận sự điều trị
▪ He’s receiving treatment for cancer.
medical treatment: điều trị y khoa
▪ They received medical treatment at the hospital after the assault.
course of treatment : đợt điều trị
▪ a course of treatment which should lead to an improvement in the patient’s condition
treatmentnounMEDICAL CARE sự điều trị; phép trị bệnh
[ C or U ] the use of drugs, exercises, etc. to cure a person of an illness or injury
_freedentaltreatment
_Perhaps it's time to try a newcourse oftreatment.
_This disease doesn't generallyrespond to(= improve as a result of) treatment.
_There are various treatmentsforthis complaint.

children.name: therapy
children.definition: a series of treatments for a problem, especially a mental one, usually without drugs or operations: phép chữa bệnh, phép điều trị, liệu pháp
examples: The therapy involves getting the patient to tell the doctor about their early childhood.
This child is clearly very disturbed emotionally and may require long-term therapy.
therapeutic[usually attri adj] [C1] relating to the treatment or cure of an illness
I find gardening very therapeutic.
Some claim that the herb has therapeutic value for treating pain.

children.name: be in therapy
examples: He’s been in therapy for years, but he’s still got a big self-esteem problem.

children.name: speech therapymedical help to improve speech
examples: Will she need to have speech therapy?

children.name: physical therapyvật lý trị liệu
examples: Don underwent months of physical therapy after the accident.

children.name: treat
children.definition: to try to make someone better when they are ill or injured, for example by giving them drugs or hospital care:
examples: điều trị , chữa trị
treat somebody for something
điều trị ai đó một cái gì đó
▪ Doctors are treating him for cancer.
treat something with something
điều trị điều gì đó với một cái gì đó
▪ Many common infections can be treated with antibiotics.
treatverbGIVE MEDICAL CARE điều trị
[ T ] to use drugs, exercises, etc. to cure a person of a disease orhealan injury
_He is being treatedfora rare skin disease.
_Western medicine tends to treatthe symptomsand not the cause.

children.name: look after sblook after/take care ofespecially British
children.definition: to spend time with achildor with someone who isoldorsick, and make sure they are safe and have the things they need:
examples: trông chừng, chăm sóc ai đó
▪ Can you look after the kids for me this afternoon?
▪ I’ve told you, I can’t come. There’s no one to look after Frieda.
▪ Jonathon has no idea what it means to take care of a baby all day long.
▪ We specialize in helping caregivers who take care of relatives in their own homes.
look aftersb/sthphrasal verb chăm sóc
to take care of or be in charge of someone or something
_We look after the neighbours' cat while they're away.
_If you look after your clothes they last a lot longer.
_[ R ]Don't worry about Mia - she can look after herself.

children.name: care for sb
children.definition: care for somebody  to look after someone who isveryillorveryoldby doing everything for them: quan tâm ai đó
examples: ▪ Elsie had to leave her job to care for her sick father.
▪ St Helen’s Hospice, which cares for the terminally ill, is holding a special fund-raising week.
▪ It is one of the only charities to care for Aids patients and ex-prisoners.
look aftersb/sthphrasal verb chăm sóc
to take care of or be in charge of someone or something
_We look after the neighbours' cat while they're away.
_If you look after your clothes they last a lot longer.
_[ R ]Don't worry about Mia - she can look after herself.

children.name: mind
children.definition: to look after children for a short time while their parents are out doing something else:
examples: để tâm
▪ The woman who minds Pip and Emma collects them from school and gives them an evening meal.
▪ Mothers who work part-time are able to mind other people’s children when they are not working.
mindverbTAKE CARE OF chăm nom; chăm sóc; trông nom
[ T ] to take care of someone or something
_She asked me if I'd mind the children for an hour while she went shopping.
_Could you mind my bag for a moment while I go to the toilet?

children.name: keep an eye on
children.definition: to stay with a child and watch them to see that they are safe, especially for a short time:
examples: để mắt tới
▪ Benjy, I want you to stay in the yard where I can keep an eye on you.
▪ Would you mind keeping an eye on Stacey while I go for a cigarette?
keep a close/careful/watchful eye on somebody để mắt cẩn thận tới ai đó
▪ He warned parents to continue to keep a close eye on their children.
keepyour/an eye onsth/sb
to watch or look after something or someone
_Will you keep your eye on my suitcase while I go to get the tickets?

children.name: nurse
children.definition: to look after someone who is ill and to make them well again or to make them comfortable:
examples: săn sóc
▪ Tony nursed his wife through her long illness without ever complaining.
▪ Irina had wanted to nurse him, but the doctors had sent her away.
nurse somebody back to health săn sóc ai đó khoẻ lại
look after a sick person until they are well again
▪ The monks tended his wounds and nursed him back to health.
nurseverb[ T ]TAKE CARE OF săn sóc,trông nom; nuôi dưỡng
to care for a person or an animal while they are ill
_He gave up his job so that he could nurse his mother at home.
_They found an injured cat and carefully nursed
itback to health(= until it was well again) .

children.name: take care of sblook after/take care ofespecially British
children.definition: to spend time with achildor with someone who isoldorsick, and make sure they are safe and have the things they need:
examples: trông chừng, chăm sóc ai đó
▪ Can you look after the kids for me this afternoon?
▪ I’ve told you, I can’t come. There’s no one to look after Frieda.
▪ Jonathon has no idea what it means to take care of a baby all day long.
▪ We specialize in helping caregivers who take care of relatives in their own homes.
take care ofsb/sthchăm sóc; chăm nom
to look after someone or something
_Takegoodcare of that girl of yours, Patrick - she's very special.
_Don't worry about me, I can take care of myself (= I do not need anyone else to protect me) .

children.name: to look after sb by helping them
take care oflook afterespecially British
children.definition: alsotakecareof  to make sure someone has everything they need and is safe and happy:
examples: trông chừng, chăm nôm
▪ We had a lovely time in Dorset. Susan looked after us very nicely. She’s a wonderful cook.
▪ Paul’s old enough to look after himself.
▪ Don’t worry about me. I can take care of myself.
be well looked after được chăm sóc tốt
always given everything you need
▪ Alex could see the horse had been well looked after.
▪ Don’t look so worried -- she’s being well looked after by the nurses.
take good care of somebody chăm sóc tốt ai đó
be very careful in order to keep somebody healthy, happy, or safe
▪ Take good care of yourself while you’re away.
▪ They took very good care of me.
▪ The firm is getting a reputation for taking better care of its customers than in the past.

children.name: look after
children.definition: alsotakecareof  to make sure someone has everything they need and is safe and happy:
examples: trông chừng, chăm nôm
▪ We had a lovely time in Dorset. Susan looked after us very nicely. She’s a wonderful cook.
▪ Paul’s old enough to look after himself.
▪ Don’t worry about me. I can take care of myself.
be well looked after được chăm sóc tốt
always given everything you need
▪ Alex could see the horse had been well looked after.
▪ Don’t look so worried -- she’s being well looked after by the nurses.
take good care of somebody chăm sóc tốt ai đó
be very careful in order to keep somebody healthy, happy, or safe
▪ Take good care of yourself while you’re away.
▪ They took very good care of me.
▪ The firm is getting a reputation for taking better care of its customers than in the past.

children.name: attend to
children.definition: to give someone the care and help that you regularly give them, especially as part of your job:

children.name: chăm lo việc gì
examples: ▪ Dr Gresham is busy at the moment attending to one of his patients.
▪ The cabin crew will attend to the passengers’ needs.
▪ They worked happily together, feeding and attending to the livestock.

children.name: take sb under your wing
children.definition: take somebody under your wing  to start to look after a younger or less experienced person in a friendly way with the intention of helping them or protecting them while they gain experience:

children.name: giúp đỡ , che chở cho ai đó
examples: ▪ Adrienne, eleven years older, had taken the 19-year-old singer under her wing.
▪ He had sized me up, he said, and had decided to take me under his wing.

children.name: to not look after sb properly
neglect
children.definition: to not look after someone properly, especially a child, although it is your responsibility to look after them:
examples: bỏ lơ
▪ He was neglected by his parents when he was very young.
▪ Staff at the hostel were accused of neglecting and abusing children in their care.
▪ Some teachers devote too much time to helping their slower students and neglect the brighter ones.
neglect[]bỏ lơ, không ngó ngàng tới
▪ increases in homelessness, child abuse and neglect
▪ He alleges that the orphanages have allowed children to die from medical neglect.
neglectverb[ T ] thờ ơ;hờ hữngvới..
to give not enough care or attention to people or things that are your responsibility
_to neglect your appearance/the garden
_He neglects that poor dog - he never takes him for walks or gives him any attention.
_I'm afraid I've rather neglected my studies this week.
neglectC1noun[ U ] sự thờ ơ;sự hờ hững/sự bỏ bê;sự bỏ mặc
when you do not give enough care or attention to someone or something, or the state of not receiving enough care or attention
_Both parents were found guilty of neglect and their child was taken away from them.
_Over the years the church has fallen into a state of neglect.

children.name: hospitalize
children.definition: , đưa vào bệnh viện;cho nhập viện
examples: UK usuallyhospitaliseverb[ T often passive ]
to take someone to hospital and keep them there for treatment
_His wife's been hospitalized for depression.
hospitalization,UK usuallyhospitalisationnoun[ U ] sự đưa vào bệnh viện; sựnhập viện

children.name: bedside manner
children.definition: noun thái độphục vụ bệnh nhân

children.name: the way in which a doctor treats people who are ill, especially in relation to kind, friendly and understanding behaviour
examples: _He has a lovely bedside manner.

children.name: in your keeping
children.definition: inyourkeeping dưới sự trông nom của ai

children.name: If something is in your keeping, you are taking care of it
examples: _I left my word processor in her keeping when I went abroad.

children.name: referral
children.definition: noun sự giới thiệu; sự chuyển đến

children.name: intensive care
children.definition: noun sự săn sóc đặc biệt
examples: (in a hospital) continuous treatment for patients who are
seriously ill, very badly injured or have just had an operation
_She needed intensive care for three weeks.

children.name: in safe keeping
children.definition: được trông nom cẩn thận;được bảo vệ chắc chắn

children.name: being carefully looked after
examples: _I left my son in safe keeping with my mother.

children.name: care
children.definition: nounPROTECTION sự chăm sóc, sự chăm nom, sự giữ gìn, sự bảo dưỡng

children.name: carerBritish /caregiverAmerican
children.definition: someone who looks after another person who is too young or ill to look after himself or herself - used especially onofficialforms, in official letters, in newspapers etc:

children.name: người chăm sóc
examples: ▪ Hospital staff can provide additional home support for carers.
▪ We have a high number of volunteer carers at the day centre.
▪ Like many caregivers, Marian gave up her job to provide 24-hour care for an elderly relative.
